subject: RE: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
msgSnippet: You are getting exactly the results I would have expected.  The test SHOULD fail.  My problem is that it doesn t fail on my systems. ... Windows 2000 java
messageBody:
You are getting exactly the results I would have expected. The test SHOULD
fail. My problem is that it doesn't fail on my systems.

Sorry that I did not specify my system type before:

---------------
Windows 2000
java version "1.3.1"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1-b24)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.3.1-b24, mixed mode)
---------------

As you see, I am also using version 1.3.1, so I am getting more and more
frustrated every second.

If I receive no confirmation from anyone where the test passes, I will just
give this up, and go lock myself up in a padded cell somewhere, since this
issue is just about driving me crazy ... :-)

Regards,

Magnus


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Berin Loritsch [mailto:bloritsch@...]
> Sent: 19. febrúar 2002 15:47
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
>
>
> Magnús Þór Torfason wrote:
> > I recently ran into a very strange bug that occurs in JUnit. I have
> > reported the bug to SUN, but they directed here, since this
> behaviour does
> > not occur in a simple standalone class.
> >
> > Attached is the unit test that I ran, as well as the output. Note
> > especially the third line:
> >
> > Class Byte: Success means that 128 > 127
> >
> > What I have found is that when a byte variable is defined as a class
> > variable within a unit test and then incremented, it is possible to
> > increment it out of the range of bytes specified by the language
> > specification in two aspects:
> >
> > 1 - Converting the byte to a string results in the string "128"
> >
> > 2 - Comparation states that the byte is larger than Byte.MAX_VALUE
> > ( (classByte > Byte.MAX_VALUE) is true )
> >
> > As the log shows, this test passes in my setup, and I have tried it on
> > several computers. Could someone in the know run this test and
> see if you
> > can figure out what is going on, because I am totally lost in this.
> >
> > Thanks and regards,
> >
> > Magnus Torfason
> >
>
>
> Here are my results (JDK 1.3.1)
>
> . Local Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
> . Static Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
> . Class Byte: Success means that -128 > 127
> F. Class Short: Success means that -32768 > 32767
> F
> Time: 0.081
> There were 2 failures:
> 1) testByteMaxValue(StrangeByteTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at StrangeByteTest.testByteMaxValue(StrangeByteTest.java:51)
> 2) testShortMaxValue(StrangeByteTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at StrangeByteTest.testShortMaxValue(StrangeByteTest.java:62)
> FAILURES!!!
> Tests run: 4, Failures: 2, Errors: 0
>
> Question:
>
> What JDK are you running? It appears you have some implicit upcasting
> to a long or something happening.
>
>
> --
>
> "They that give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety
> deserve neither liberty nor safety."
> - Benjamin Franklin
>
>
